newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crudes weaker, more Minas deals said done.
newsitem.headline: Asian crudes weaker, more Minas deals said done.

text.p: Crude oil prices were moderately weaker on Thursday with talk of more Minas deals while the Brent/Dubai spread narrowed slightly following Brent's overnight losses.
Traders said players were easing into the October MidEast market and the September regional market but with little urgency.
Brent/Dubai narrowed following the second-day Wednesday of a market correction in Brent. Brent/Dubai for October to $1.85/$1.95 per barrel, in from $1.85/$2.05 on Wednesday.
Dubai intermonth spreads were steady around 30 cents for October/November and November/December.
Paper Tapis fell, tracking the overnight fall on Brent and NYMEX. September paper Tapis was assessed $20.95/$21.05, down 15 cents from a day-earlier.
General talk on regional grades was quiet but another Minas deal was heard done -- 200,000 barrels at ICP minus 25 cents per barrel to a U.S. major.
In addition, 100,000 barrels were heard done to a Japanese refinery at ICP minus 30 cents. Both deals could not be immediately confirmed.
The deals added to a Tuesday deal when a major sold 200,000 barrels of Minas to Korean refinery at ICP less 25 cents.
A major was said to have sold an October Murban cargo at ADNOC +15 cents, but some traders suggested the talk was speculative.
Workers at Shell's 115,000 barrels-per-day refinery in Australia voted to return to work Friday after walking out over a pay dispute August 13.
